user_prompt: Suppose that tidal power, solar power, and wind power are the leading renewable energy sources. Forecasts indicate it’s likely tidal power will generate the most electricity this year, followed by solar power, with wind power capacity lagging significantly behind. These are the only major sources, so if solar power doesn’t generate the most electricity, then if tidal power doesn’t, wind power will. Moreover, tidal power likely will generate the most electricity and hence solar power likely won't. Does it follow that it's likely that, if tidal power doesn't generate the most electricity, wind power will?
system_prompt:
Critical reasoning about nested conditionals with probabilities:

Given three options X, Y, Z where P(X) > P(Y) > P(Z), if X doesn't occur, then Y becomes the most likely, NOT Z.

The nested conditional "if X doesn't happen, then if Y doesn't happen, Z will happen" does NOT make "if X doesn't happen, Z will happen" likely. Why? Because when X is eliminated, Y still has higher probability than Z.

Example: If P(X)=0.50, P(Y)=0.35, P(Z)=0.15, then P(Z|not X) = 0.15/(0.35+0.15) = 0.30, which is not likely.

The inference only holds when Z's probability is close to Y's, which contradicts the premise that Z has "much lower odds."

Answer with only 'yes' or 'no' - nothing else.
